In the eyes of many umpires, a tie actually goes to the fielder. The rationale is that the umpire makes his judgment by comparing the sound of the ball hitting the glove with his view of the runner's foot hitting the bag. Because sound travels much slower than light, if the sound is perceived at the same time as visual contact, then the ball actually got there first and the runner is out.

So it's possible to analyze if pitchers up until the 1980s pitched better in the postseason on 3 days rest (when they were trained to do so) than the pitchers after 2000 who have usually struggled in the postseason on 3 days rest (when they haven't been trained to do so).

The problem is that it's not _really_ possible to analyze that, because there are too few of them, and there's somewhat of a selection bias likely at play: you had knuckleballers and certain kinds of pitchers (Maddux like) who didn't really need the power that modern pitchers seem to. Essentially, you had pitchers who were capable of pitching competently on three days rest doing so; but it was a very small number of them. The modern pitchers doing so in the playoffs are basically normal (but star-level) pitchers, who might not be well suited to the task generally.

The more natural experiment would be does 5 days rest versus *6* days rest make a difference (in which case you could suggest that 4 vs 5 makes a difference); many teams use true 5 man rotations, which means pitchers will sporadically and randomly pitch with 6 days rest and 5 days rest (ie, an unbiased random selection). This doesn't answer the question of do pitchers get tired pitching too much, but it does answer the question of is a single start superior when on an extra day of rest, which is also interesting.
